column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2

#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Nissa
#Text=Nissa is an archaeological site in Ahal Province , Turkmenistan .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Nissa is one of the most important sites of the Parthian Empire .
#Text=The Parthians ruled in Persia from 247 BC to 228 AD .
#Text=They defeated the Seleucids ( successors of Alexander the Great ) and conquered great parts of the Middle East and southwest Asia .
#Text=The earliest settlements in the area of Nissa date back to the 4th millenium BC .
#Text=In the 3rd century BC the Parthians built an impressive fortress at Old Nisa and erected a royal residence , which probably was the first royal residence of the Parthian kings .
#Text=The city was named Mithradatkert ( fortress of Mithradates ) during the reign of King Mithradates the Great ( 174-138 BC ) .
#Text=Greek sources refer to the city as administrative and economic centre during the reign of the Arsacid dynasty .
#Text=The Arsacid dynasty conquered a huge area from the Indus to the Euphrates and Nisa became an important city on the crossroads of many cultures from Persia , Greece and Central Asia .
#Text=New Nisa was conquered by the Arabian Caliphate in the 7th century and became part of the Seljuk Empire in the 11th century .
#Text=Archaeological research at the site began in the 1930s .
#Text=Since 1990 it is excavated by the University of Torino , Italy ( Centro Scavi di Torino ) .
#Text=In 2007 , the fortresses of Nissa were declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site .
#Text=Get in
#Text=The Parthian Fortresses of Nisa are located 15 km southwest of Ashgabat near the village of Bagir in the Akhal District of Turkmenistan .
#Text=Buses , marshrutkas and taxis depart from the western side of Teke Bazaar in Ashgabat .
#Text=The ride in a minibus to Old Nisa costs US$ 0.20 .
#Text=The cost of bus ticket is 0.2012:00 - 23:00 | price=US$ 1 - 2.
#Text=With public transport it is only possible to reach Bagir village .
#Text=From a roundabout in the centre of the village it is pleasant 2 km walk uphill to Old Nisa and the same distance to New Nisa .
#Text=Get around
#Text=The site is small enough to explore it conveniently on foot .
#Text=See
#Text=Partian Fortresses of Nissa .
#Text=08:00-18:00. ( Old Nisa and New Nisa )
#Text=US$ 1 .
#Text=Old Nisa is a natural hill , about 14 ha wide , surrounded by high defensive earthen ramparts with 40 rectangular towers , The top of the hill was flattened and levelled with layers of earth .
#Text=Number and location of gates have not yet been identified .
#Text=It is presumed that the main ( and perhaps the only ) entrances was at the center of the western part of the surrounding wall .
#Text=The fortress constist of a Northern Complex and a Central Complex .
#Text=The Northern Complex includes the so-called large square building in which the royal treasury , wine vaults and auxiliary buildings have been identified .

#Text=In this area , the most famous pieces of art of Old Nisa , as the Rodogoune marble statue , the Goddess of Nisa marble statue , elaborate ivory rhythons ( drinking vessels ) , fragments of royal thrones and more than 2000 pieces of ceramics ( ostraka ) representing house keeping documents were discovered .
#Text=The Central Complex consists of a Building with the Square Hall , a Building with the Round Hall , a Tower-like Building , a North-Eastern Building and a Columned Hall .
#Text=The Building with the Square Hall is the most important building of the Central Complex .
#Text=It covers an area of about 1,000 m ² and has walls up to 5 m thick .
#Text=The North-Eastern Building consist of two decorated yards and rooms for domestic uses .
#Text=It is considered as the palace of the Arsacid dynasty .
#Text=The Tower-like Building has a massive aquare base of 20 by 20 m. It is encircled by two rows of dark corridors , lit by narrow windows .
#Text=The upper parts show traces of architectural decor and wall paintings depicting battle scenes .
#Text=It houses a small museum of paintings and architectural elements .
#Text=The Building with the Round Hall is a square building with a round hall of 17 m in diameter .
#Text=The building served religious purposes , it is , however , unclear if it was a temple , a mausoleum or the shrine of a hero .
#Text=The Columned Hall consists of a large rectangular hall with four columns in the middle and served ceremonial purposes .
#Text=New Nisa is located about 1.5 km north-west of Old Nisa .
#Text=The tell with a surface of about 25 ha is surrounded on all sides by powerful walls with a height up to 9 m.
#Text=It has two entrances ( one from Bagyr village and one from the North West ) .
#Text=In Parthian times , the city was divided into two parts , the upper city ( ark ) and the lower city ( shakhristan ) .
#Text=The layout clearly indicates a densely populated town .
#Text=The Parthian buildings are interpreted as remains of the fortress , burial houses and storehouses .
